'''[[Kingdom of Great Britain|British]]''': 1713–present |garrison = |current_commander = |commanders = |occupants = |battles = |events = |image2 = [[File:Map of the Moorish Castle.gif|200px|Map of the Moorish Castle.]] |caption2 = {{ordered list |list_style_type=upper-alpha |style=text-align: left; |1=Inner and outer keep |2=Qasbah |3=Villa Vieja |4=Port (Barcina) }}{{ordered list |style=text-align: left; |1=Tower of Homage |2=Flanking Wall |3=Gate of Granada |4=Gatehouse |5=Tower |6=Giralda Tower ([[North Bastion, Gibraltar|North Bastion]]) |7=[[Landport (Gibraltar)|Landport]] |8=Sea Gate ([[Grand Casemates Gates]]) |9=Barcina Gate |10=Galley House }} }} '''The Moorish Castle''' is the name given to a [[medieval fortification]] in [[Gibraltar]] comprising various buildings, gates, and fortified walls, with the dominant features being the Tower of Homage and the Gate House. Part of the castle itself also housed [[Her Majesty's Prison Service|the prison]] of Gibraltar until it was relocated in 2010. The Tower of Homage is clearly visible to all visitors to Gibraltar; not only because of its striking construction, but also because of its dominant and strategic position. Although sometimes compared to the nearby ''[[Alcázar|alcazars]]'' in [[Spain]], the Moorish Castle in Gibraltar was constructed by the [[Marinid dynasty]], making it unique in the [[Iberian Peninsula]].{{Cite web |date=May 1998 | url=http://www.maltwood.uvic.ca/cam/publications/CAM_bulletins/004_heritage_of_gibralter.html | title=The Heritage of Gibralter: A Reply | work=CAM Bulletins | publisher=Commonwealth Association of Museums | accessdate=2012-09-10}} ==History== [[File:View of Moorish Castle from Grand Battery.jpg|thumb|left|View of the Moorish Castle's northern defences as seen from the [[Grand Battery]] in 1879]] [[File:Queen Charlottes Battery.jpg|thumb|left|250px|[[Queen Charlotte's Battery]] at the Moorish Castle.]] Gibraltar has always been of special significance to the numerous peoples and civilizations that have visited or occupied it over the ages, from the [[Neanderthal]] period, through the Classical and on to [[Moorish architecture|Moorish]], [[Spain|Spanish]], and the current [[United Kingdom|British]] rule. The Moorish occupation is by far the longest in Gibraltar's recorded history, having lasted from 711 to 1309 and then again from 1350 to 1462, a total of 710 years.{{Cite web | url=http://www.guide-to-castles-of-europe.com/moorish-castle.html | title=Moorish Castle | publisher=Guide to the Castles of Europe | accessdate=2012-09-13}} Historical importance of Gibraltar to both [[Muslim]]s and [[Christian]]s lies in the fact that the [[Umayyad conquest of Hispania|Moorish invasion]] and occupation of parts of western [[Europe]] started from [[Gibraltar]] in 711 and, through to its final recapture by Spaniards in 1462, Moorish rule was gradually undermined until, with the fall of [[Granada]] in 1492, Moorish occupation of parts of western Europe came to an end after 781 years. The Moorish conquest of [[Spain]] was led by [[Tarik ibn Ziyad]] and [[Musa ibn Nusayr]], who may have landed in Europe at or near Gibraltar. Gibraltar thus became the stepping-stone to the Moorish conquests of most of Spain and part of France. This spectacular feat of arms took a mere twenty-one years, no mean task considering the distances and terrain involved, and the fact that mechanical transport on land was not then in use.{{Cite web | url=http://www.gibraltar.gov.gi | title=Information on the Moorish Castle Complex | publisher=Government of Gibraltar | accessdate=2007-02-13}} The strategic importance of Gibraltar rose in the last years of the Moorish rule, when, after the successful Spanish reconquest of the entire Guadalquivir valley, Gibraltar became one of the key elements in communication between the [[Kingdom of Granada]] and Moorish domains in northwestern Africa. Construction of the Moorish Castle commenced in the 8th century AD (possibly AD 711);{{dubious|date=November 2012}} the date of its completion is not recorded. Its walls enclosed a considerable area, reaching down from the upper part of the [[Rock of Gibraltar]] to the sea. The most conspicuous remaining parts of the Castle are the upper tower, or Tower of Homage, together with various terraces and battlements below it, and the massive Gate House, with its cupola roof.{{Cite web | url=http://www.gib.gi/heritage/castle.html#galley | title=Gibraltar Heritage Trust History of The Moorish Castle | accessdate=2007-02-13 | deadurl=yes | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070206031404/http://www.gib.gi/heritage/castle.html#galley | archivedate=2007-02-06 | df= }} ==The Tower of Homage== The Tower of Homage is the highest tower of the period of Islamic rule in the [[Iberian Peninsula]], and the [[Qasbah]] of the Castle is the largest in the area. The Castle itself played a prominent part in the Muslim invasion of the Iberian Peninsula, with Muslim forces overrunning a large portion of it in two years - an invasion which led to Islamic domination of parts of western Europe for more than seven centuries. It is therefore of historic significance not only for [[Gibraltar]] and [[Iberian Peninsula|Iberia]], but also for all of western [[Europe]]. The present Tower of Homage, and most of what is visible today of the Castle, was rebuilt during the second Moorish period of occupation in the early 14th century, after its near destruction during a reconquest of Gibraltar by the Moors following a re-occupation by Spanish forces from 1309 to 1333. ==Present day== Today the Moorish Castle is one of the major tourist attractions of Gibraltar, and it is shown on the reverse of the 1995 design (still in circulation) of the [[Gibraltar Pound|Gibraltar five-pound banknote]].{{Cite web | url=http://www.currencymuseum.net/images/gibraltar25-1995r.JPG | title=World Paper Money - Image of the reverse of a 1995 £5 Gibraltar banknote | format=JPEG | work=Will's Online World Paper Money Gallery | accessdate=2012-09-13}} The name "Moorish Castle" (or "''El Castillo''" in Spanish) is also used locally when referring to the residential area surrounding the Castle, location of the ''Moorish Castle Estate''. Part of the castle itself housed [[Her Majesty's Prison Service|the prison]] of Gibraltar until the prison was relocated in 2010.{{cite web | url=http://www.chronicle.gi/headlines_details.php?id=19885 | title=GATES CLOSE, ‘WINDY’ PRISON OPENS FOR BUSINESS | accessdate=2010-09-01 | last=Mascarenhas | first=Alice | date=2010-09-01 | work=The Gibraltar Chronicle | publisher=The Gibraltar Chronicle | archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5sQXDDEHx?url=http://www.chronicle.gi/headlines_details.php?id=19885 | archivedate=2010-09-01 | deadurl=yes | df= }} ==See also== {{commons category|Moorish Castle, Gibraltar}} * [[History of Gibraltar]] {{clear}} ==References== {{Reflist}} {{Fortifications of Gibraltar}} {{Buildings in Gibraltar}} {{Gibraltar topics}} {{List of castles in Europe}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Castles In The United Kingdom And Ireland}} [[Category:Castles in Gibraltar]] [[Category:Islam in Gibraltar]] [[Category:Medieval architecture]] [[Category:Moorish architecture of the Iberian peninsula]] [[Category:Marinid architecture]] [[Category:Almohad architecture]] [[Category:Archaeological sites in Gibraltar]] [[Category:Arabs in Gibraltar]] [[Category:Berbers in Gibraltar]] [[Category:Castles in the United Kingdom| ]] [[Category:Lists of castles in the United Kingdom| ]] [[Category:8th-century fortifications]] [[Category:Castles in British Overseas Territories]]

{{for|the song referenced in the fan fiction|My Immortal}} '''''My Immortal''''' is a ''[[Harry Potter]]'' [[fan fiction]] serially published on [[FanFiction.Net]] between 2006 and 2007. Known for its incomprehensible narrative and constant digressions, the story centers on a 17-year-old female vampire, a non-canonical character, and her relationships with the characters of the ''Harry Potter'' series, most notably her romantic relationship with [[Draco Malfoy]]. Ultimately, she is prompted by visions to travel back in time to try to defeat the main [[antagonist]] of the series, [[Lord Voldemort]].
Since the beginning of the work's publication, it has garnered infamy for bad writing, inconsistency, and disregard for the ''Harry Potter'' source material. Often regarded as among the worst fan fiction written, ''My Immortal'' is felt to be a detriment to those attempting to bring legitimacy to fan fiction. Despite this, the series has also inspired multiple derivative works, including a [[YouTube]] web series, and is viewed with nostalgia for adolescent fan life.
The author's identity has never been confirmed and has been deemed by many as "unsolvable". The author published the story under the username "XXXbloodyrists666XXX" and self-identified as Tara Gilesbie. In September 2017, someone claiming to be the author updated a [[FictionPress]] account stating that she had created an active [[Tumblr]] account under her real name; an effort to locate this Tumblr account resulted in the account of [[Young adult fiction|young adult]] novelist Rose Christo. She has since stated that she was one of two co-authors of ''My Immortal'', and had provided evidence of her authorship to [[Macmillan Publishers]], but controversy that same month over factual errors in her then-forthcoming memoirs has led to doubt as to her authorship.
The story has been speculated to be a hoax designed to either [[Internet troll|troll]] readers or to [[Satire|satirize]] fan fiction, but the work and the alleged online presence of the author has also been described as too elaborate and too time-consuming to fake effectively. In September 2017, Christo stated that ''My Immortal'' is a work of satire, though any evidence of this is tied to her own claims of authorship.
==Background and publication== The work was published to [[FanFiction.Net]] between early 2006 and 2007, ultimately totaling 44 chapters and nearly 22,700 words.<ref name="Vulture">{{Cite web|url=http://www.vulture.com/2015/03/bizarre-unsolved-mystery-of-my-immortal.html|title=The Bizarre, Unsolved Mystery of ‘My Immortal,’ the World’s Worst Fanfiction Story|last=Riesman|first=Abraham|date=March 12, 2015|website=|publisher=[[Vulture.com]]|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151125172838/http://www.vulture.com/2015/03/bizarre-unsolved-mystery-of-my-immortal.html|archivedate=November 25, 2015|deadurl=no|accessdate=November 28, 2015|df=}}</ref> The forty-fourth chapter was accompanied by an author's note explaining that the author was leaving "{{sic|dubya}}", commonly believed to be [[Dubai]], and the chapter would be the last until the author's return.<ref name="Vulture" /><ref name="TheVerge">{{Cite web|url=https://www.theverge.com/2013/12/10/5166462/the-worst-thing-ever-written-a-history-of-trollfic|title=The Worst Thing Ever Written|last=Robertson|first=Adi|date=December 10, 2013|website=|publisher=[[The Verge]]|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151202084919/http://www.theverge.com/2013/12/10/5166462/the-worst-thing-ever-written-a-history-of-trollfic|archivedate=December 2, 2015|deadurl=no|accessdate=November 28, 2015|df=}}</ref> However, no further chapters were published. It was removed by site administrators in 2008, a few months after its last chapter was published. However, it survives in [[Cut, copy, and paste|copied-and-pasted]] versions across the Internet.<ref name="Vulture" /> The work apparently takes its name from the song "[[My Immortal]]" by [[Evanescence]].<ref name="TheVerge" /><ref name="DailyDot">{{Cite web|url=http://www.dailydot.com/fandom/worst-harry-potter-fanfic-my-immortal-web-series/|title=The worst "Harry Potter" fanfic ever is now a hilarious webseries|last=Baker-Whitelaw|first=Gavia|date=July 29, 2013|website=|publisher=''[[The Daily Dot]]''|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160612122150/http://www.dailydot.com/fandom/worst-harry-potter-fanfic-my-immortal-web-series/|archivedate=June 12, 2016|deadurl=no|access-date=June 12, 2016|df=}}</ref>
==Style and genre== ''My Immortal'' is split into 44 brief chapters. Author's notes, indicated by "AN", precede and are dispersed throughout the narrative prose. These notes are written in a largely [[phonetic spelling]] and characterized the author as "standoffish". As the work progressed, these author's notes increasingly became "defensive, impenetrable, and prone to mentioning [[suicide attempt]]s" and defended the work's poor spelling and deviation from canon characterization from negative reviewers.<ref name="Vulture" />
[[Abraham Riesman]] of [[Vulture.com]] described the prose as having "awkward rhythm, strange digressions, and stultifyingly [[purple prose]]" and noted that the work is "agonizing" to a regular fan fiction reader because of "all the hated [[Trope (literature)|tropes]]" it employs in the opening passage alone.<ref name="Vulture" /> [[Adi Robertson]] of ''[[The Verge]]'' observed that the quality of the prose declined after the twelfth chapter, when the work's editor had a falling out with the author and became temporarily uninvolved with the work; even after the editor and author reconciled, Robertson felt that the prose "never recovered".<ref name="TheVerge" /> [[Gavia Baker-Whitelaw]] of ''[[The Daily Dot]]'' noted the work "featured all the hallmarks of terrible fanfic: hundreds of grammar and spelling mistakes, a nonsensical storyline, and a [[Mary Sue]] protagonist who was clearly a glorified version of the author" and pointed out the numerous descriptions of the protagonist's [[Hot Topic]] outfits.<ref name="DailyDot" />
The work is characterized by misspellings permeating both the work itself and the author's notes, to the point that the names of the protagonist and canonical ''Harry Potter'' characters are frequently and variously misspelled.<ref name="Vulture" /><ref name="DailyDot" />
The work has also been noted to fail to adhere to ''Harry Potter'' canon. It features "an incredibly OOC [out-of-character] ''Harry Potter'' universe"<ref name="TheMarySue">{{Cite web|url=http://www.themarysue.com/my-immortal-webseries/|title=Infamously Bad ''Harry Potter'' Fanfic ''My Immortal'' Gets Web Series|last=Jaffe|first=Brooke|date=July 29, 2013|website=|publisher=[[The Mary Sue]]|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160713124934/http://www.themarysue.com/my-immortal-webseries/|archivedate=July 13, 2016|deadurl=no|access-date=June 12, 2016|df=}}</ref> where "at no point do any of the ''Harry Potter'' characters act even slightly like themselves".<ref name="io9">{{Cite web|url=http://io9.gizmodo.com/the-most-infamously-awful-fanfic-ever-my-immortal-h-961749327|title=The most infamously awful fanfic ever, "My Immortal," has a web series|last=Bricken|first=Rob|date=July 30, 2013|website=|publisher=[[io9]]|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160616021429/http://io9.gizmodo.com/the-most-infamously-awful-fanfic-ever-my-immortal-h-961749327|archivedate=June 16, 2016|deadurl=no|access-date=June 12, 2016|df=}}</ref> References to "decidedly un-Harry Potterish bands" such as [[My Chemical Romance]] have also been noted.<ref name="DailyDot" />
Chapters 39 and 40, according to the author's notes, were written by a hacker, and the writing in both chapters was a "much more controlled prose that read like a lampoon of the previous 38".<ref name="Vulture" />
==Authorship== ===2006–2016: Speculation on authorship and genre=== ''My Immortal'' was published under the username "XXXbloodyrists666XXX", and the author also used the name "Tara Gilesbie". Author's notes in the story identified a friend nicknamed Raven, operating under the username "bloodytearz666", as the work's editor and [[beta reader]]. Later author's notes claimed that someone hacked into Gilesbie's account and wrote chapters 39 and 40.<ref name="Vulture" />
The true identity of the author became subject to wide speculation, and since the publication of the final chapter, various individuals have claimed to have written the work in jest or as a hoax.<ref name="Vulture" /> Due to its "systematically terrible" quality, the work is often believed to be a [[satire]] or [[parody]] of fan fiction.<ref name="Vulture" /><ref name="DailyDot" />
At the same time, the "exceedingly complicated" details of the work, including a series of related online accounts outside of FanFiction.net and the effort of writing a work of such length, led to a "consensus" among users of [[Encyclopedia Dramatica]]—a website notorious for online trolling and dedicated to cataloging "internet culture" — that it would be too difficult to fake and that Gilesbie was writing sincerely, a sentiment apparently shared by other online communities who mocked the author.<ref name="Vulture" /> [[Brad Kim]], editor of [[Know Your Meme]], supported the work as genuine, citing his experiences with writing workshops on [[LiveJournal]] and [[Xanga]] where he encountered similar works, as "these were the kinds of things that would be formulated by a high-school teenager in the early 2000s".<ref name="Vulture" /> Writing for [[Vulture.com]], Abraham Riesman wrote that "[t]he mystery of the authorship of 'My Immortal' — even in this privacy-averse age — appears unsolvable."<ref name="Vulture" />
===2017: Rose Christo co-authorship claim=== Rose Christo, author of [[Young adult fiction|young adult novels]], began writing a memoir about her alleged experiences as a [[Native Americans in the United States|Native American]] child in the New York [[Foster care in the United States|foster care system]] titled ''Under the Same Stars: the Search for my Brother and the True Story of My Immortal''. The memoir details the period of time during which she allegedly co-wrote ''My Immortal''. [[Macmillan Publishers]] allegedly hired a lawyer to verify Christo's claims over the course of three days; she claimed to have provided proof through the email address with which she created the FanFiction.net account and a [[USB flash drive|flash drive]] containing the first eleven unedited chapters of ''My Immortal''.<ref name=":1" /><ref name=":2" />
In March 2017, Christo quietly stated on her [[Tumblr]] account that she co-wrote ''My Immortal''; however, the post gained little notice. In early August 2017, Christo posted an update to a previously unknown FictionPress account seemingly related to Tara Gilesbie that similarly received little attention.<ref name=":3">{{Cite web|url=https://www.vox.com/culture/2017/9/13/16275802/who-wrote-my-immortal-tara-rose-christo|title=My Immortal: solving the mystery of the internet’s most beloved — and notorious — fanfic|last=Romano|first=Aja|date=September 13, 2017|website=|publisher=[[Vox (website)|Vox]]|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=September 13, 2017}}</ref>
Later in August, an [[Self-publishing|independently published]] ''Handbook for Mortals'' came to public attention after it was discovered that its sales were artificially inflated to push it to the top of the young adult [[The New York Times Best Seller list|''New York Times'' Best Seller list]], from which it was subsequently removed.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.latimes.com/books/la-et-jc-handbook-for-mortals-bestseller-ya-20170824-story.html |title=Did a YA book buy its way to the top of the New York Times bestseller list? |work=LA Times |author=Jessica Roy |date=August 24, 2017 |accessdate=August 25, 2017}}</ref><ref name=Italie>{{cite news|last1=Italie|first1=Hillel|title=Book Pulled From Best-Seller List|url=http://time.com/4917209/ny-times-best-seller-handbook-for-mortals/|accessdate=September 11, 2017|work=Time|agency=Associated Press|date=August 26, 2017}}</ref> Writing similarities between the novel and ''My Immortal'' led to speculation that ''Handbook for Mortals'' author [[Lani Sarem]] was the author of ''My Immortal''. Christo again updated the FictionPress account to say she was not Sarem. She also posted on FictionPress to state that her only social media account was on Tumblr, which operated under her real name.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.dailydot.com/parsec/my-immortal-fanfic-2017-update/|title=Did the mysterious fanfic author behind ‘My Immortal’ just resurface?|last=Baker-Whitelaw|first=Gavia|date=August 31, 2017|website=|publisher=''[[The Daily Dot]]''|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170831214232/https://www.dailydot.com/parsec/my-immortal-fanfic-2017-update/|archive-date=2017-08-31|dead-url=no|access-date=August 31, 2017|df=}}</ref> An editorial assistant at Macmillan Publishers also stated that Sarem was not the author of ''My Immortal'' and stated that MacMillan was to publish the author's memoir.<ref name=":3" /><ref name=":4" />
These statements sparked a search for the claimed Tumblr account, which was found as Christo's in early September. By September 5, Christo stated on her Tumblr account that she co-wrote ''My Immortal'' and that she had provided proof to her publisher [[Macmillan Publishers (United States)|Macmillan Publishers]], later reported by [[BuzzFeed]],<ref name=":4">{{Cite web|url=https://www.buzzfeed.com/alannabennett/my-immortal-author-hi-vampire|title=People Think They Have The Answer To The Decade-Long Mystery Of Who Wrote "My Immortal"|last=Bennett|first=Alanna|date=September 5, 2017|website=|publisher=[[Buzzfeed]]|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=September 7, 2017}}</ref> and on September 7, BuzzFeed published her first official statement as the alleged author of ''My Immortal.''<ref name=":2">{{Cite web|url=https://www.buzzfeed.com/alannabennett/exclusive-first-look-under-same-stars-my-immortal-memoir|title=The Story Of "My Immortal" Is More Wild And Heartbreaking Than You Imagined|last=Bennett|first=Alanna|date=September 7, 2017|website=|publisher=[[Buzzfeed]]|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=September 7, 2017}}</ref> She said of her decision to publicly identify herself as a co-author: "I would never have come forward about ''My Immortal'' if not for the fact that it coincided with the things that happened to me as a teen."<ref name=":2" />
Later that month, a forum post on Kiwi Farms, a forum notorious for perpetrating [[doxing]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://nymag.com/selectall/2016/07/kiwi-farms-the-webs-biggest-community-of-stalkers.html|title=Kiwi Farms, the Web’s Biggest Community of Stalkers|last=Pless|first=Margaret|date= July 19, 2016|website=|publisher=''[[New York (magazine)|New York]]''|access-date=November 4, 2017|quote=}}</ref> by Christo's brother (the subject of her memoir), verified as such by the forum operators, refuted several of Christo's claims in the upcoming memoir, including those of their ancestry and shared childhood history.<ref name=":5" /><ref name=":6">{{Cite web|url=https://www.hypable.com/my-immortal-and-5-unanswered-burning-questions/|title=The ‘My Immortal’ mystery grows: Five new questions after the memoir’s cancellation|last=Bryne-Cristiano|first=Laura|date=October 5, 2017|website=|publisher=Hypable|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=October 6, 2017}}</ref> The memoir was subsequently canceled by MacMillan after an investigation found factual errors in her narrative; Christo stated that these errors had been purposefully made in an attempt to protect her family's identity.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.buzzfeed.com/jarrylee/the-my-immortal-book-is-no-longer-going-to-be-published|title=The "My Immortal" Book Is No Longer Going To Be Published|last=Lee|first=Jarry|date=October 3, 2017|website=|publisher=[[Buzzfeed]]|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=October 5, 2017}}</ref> Christo's brother has additionally said that he does not know if Christo wrote ''My Immortal'' and that she enjoyed ridiculing badly written fan fiction.<ref name=":5">{{Cite web|url=https://moviepilot.com/p/brother-of-my-immortal-author-casts-serious-doubt-on-her-claims/4383046|title=The Author Of 'My Immortal' Is A Fake And I Don't Know What To Believe Anymore|last=Tremeer|first=Eleanor|date=October 5, 2017|website=Movie Pilot|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=October 5, 2017}}</ref><ref name=":6" /> Christo confirmed via Tumblr in October that her original name was Theresa Rose Christodoulopoulos, confirmed her brother's identity, conceded to many of his revelations about her, but also disagreed with a few of his claims and reiterated her claim that she was one of the authors of ''My Immortal''.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://rosechristo1.tumblr.com/post/166154457119/hey-guys-im-still-around-so-it-looks-like-a-few|title=kamakisikaw - Rose Christo's Tumblr account|last=Christo|first=Rose|date=October 7, 2017|website=[[Tumblr]]|archive-url=https://www.webcitation.org/6u2t5THqM?url=https://rosechristo1.tumblr.com/post/166154457119/hey-guys-im-still-around-so-it-looks-like-a-few#|archive-date=2017-10-07|dead-url=yes|access-date=October 7, 2017|df=}}</ref> She closed the Tumblr account a few days later. ''[[Vox (website)|Vox]]'' described Christo's authorship claim as one of the more likely claims she has made, though still in some doubt.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.vox.com/culture/2017/10/9/16428248/my-immortal-still-a-mystery-rose-christo-fake |title=The My Immortal memoir has been canceled, and the mystery of the notorious fanfic deepens |date=2017-10-09 |accessdate=2017-10-09 |publisher=[[Vox (website)|Vox]]}}</ref>
==Plot summary== The [[protagonist]] of the story is Ebony (occasionally Enoby, Eboby, Evony, Ebory, Enobby, Enopby, Egogy, Tara, or TaEbory) Dark'ness Dementia Raven Way, a seventeen-year-old [[vampire]] who attends [[Hogwarts]] (located in [[England]] instead of the original books' [[Scotland]]) as a member of [[Slytherin|Slytherin House]]. Hogwarts is depicted as being divided between two [[clique]]s, the "[[Goth subculture|goffs]]" and the [[Preppy|preps]]. Ebony and all the [[sympathetic character]]s are part of the goth clique while the members of the prep clique are portrayed unsympathetically. Many of the main characters of ''Harry Potter'' are given {{Sic|"goffik"}} makeovers, moved to the Slytherin House, and renamed.
The story begins by focusing on Ebony entering a relationship with [[Draco Malfoy]], who is depicted as shy, sensitive and [[bisexuality|bisexual]]. Ebony and Draco have sex in the [[Hogwarts|Forbidden Forest]], but are witnessed by Hogwarts' principal [[Albus Dumbledore]] (often referred to as "Albert Dumblydore"), who yells at them and derides them as {{Sic|"motherfukers"}}. Later, after learning that Draco used to date [[Harry Potter (character)|Harry "Vampire" Potter]] (a nickname he gained because he "love[s] the taste of human blood"), Ebony becomes so angry that she runs crying into the Forbidden Forest, where she meets [[Lord Voldemort]]. Voldemort, speaking in faux-archaic English (unlike his teenaged self from the 80s), gives her a [[gun]] and demands that she kill "Vampire" Potter or else he will kill Draco, but Ebony refuses. Later on, Draco learns of this encounter and he is so angry that Ebony kept it from him that he commits [[suicide]] by [[self-harm|slitting his wrists]].
In a subsequent scene, however, Vampire has a [[vision (spirituality)|vision]] of Draco being held prisoner by Voldemort. The discrepancy between this and the earlier depiction of Draco having committed suicide is not explained. After rescuing Draco from Voldemort, Ebony and her friends attend a [[My Chemical Romance]] concert in [[Places in Harry Potter#Hogsmeade|Hogsmeade]]. After some songs have been played, the concert ends abruptly when the members of My Chemical Romance reveal themselves to be Voldemort and his [[Death Eater]]s. Voldemort, who had been disguised as lead vocalist [[Gerard Way]], proclaims his intent to kill Ebony and Draco for the former's failure to kill Vampire, but they are saved by Albus Dumbledore, who has just given himself a gothic makeover. The next day, Dumbledore gives a gothic makeover to the Hogwarts Great Hall as well, but Ebony feels that he is a [[poseur]] and dislikes him greatly, a sentiment shared by her friends.
During this time, [[Death Eater#Lucius Malfoy|Lucius Malfoy]] and [[Order of the Phoenix (fictional organisation)#Sirius Black|Sirius Black]] are inexplicably shot by a gun-toting "black guy" (likely meant to be [[Blade (comics)|Blade]] given the vampire themes). There is also a secondary plot point in which [[Professor Trelawney]] ("Trevolry") / [[Professor Sinistra]] ("Sinister", "Sinatra"), combined into one character, has an addiction to what is presumably the truth serum [[Veritaserum]]. A third plot point sees [[Hogwarts staff#Minerva McGonagall|Professor McGonagall]] (often referred to as "Mc[[Google]]" or "McGoggles") and [[Severus Snape]] (often called "Snap", or "Snope" at times) attempting to rape or harm the protagonists. Yet another plot point follows [[Order of the Phoenix (fictional organisation)#Remus Lupin|Remus Lupin]] and Snape being bisexuals who spy on Ebony, at one point resulting in a moment shortly after Draco's "death" where they are sitting on their broomsticks with "Loopin {{Sic|[[Masturbation|masticating]]}}" to Ebony bathing. In addition, [[Rubeus Hagrid|Hagrid]] is inexplicably a teenaged Hogwarts student who has a crush on Ebony, and who is also a Satanist.
Ebony begins having mysterious visions, which she is told indicates she must [[time travel|travel back in time]] (using a [[pensieve]]) to stop Tom Riddle from becoming Voldemort by seducing him, and to retrieve a cure for Sinister/Trevolry's addiction to "Volxemortserum". Arriving in the past, she meets the young Riddle, who calls himself "[[Satan]]", and who has been mistakenly referred to as "[[Neo (The Matrix)|Tom Anderson]]", "[[Tom Bombadil]]", and "Stan". "Satan" is in a band with [[James Potter (character)|James Potter]], Severus Snape, Sirius Black, and [[Lucius Malfoy]]. He is uncanonically depicted attending Hogwarts at the same time as the Marauders in what is further uncanonically portrayed as the 1980s. The author points out a few [[anachronism]]s in these scenes, telling readers to ignore them. There is also an unexplained cameo by a gothic [[Marty McFly]], who gives Ebony a black [[DeLorean time machine]] able to transform into an [[iPod]], allowing her to travel forward in time.
Eventually, Ebony brings "Satan" forward in time, where he morphs into the present-day Voldemort. This leads to a confrontation between the forces of good and evil in the Great Hall. The story ends ambiguously with Ebony firing off an [[Avada Kedavra]] curse, which is misrepresented as "[[abracadabra|abra kedabra]]".
==Reception== {{Expand section|date=July 2016}} Before its removal from FanFiction.Net, ''My Immortal'' allegedly gained between 8,000<ref name="TheVerge" /><ref name=":0">{{Cite book|title=The Ultimate Guide to the Harry Potter Fandom|last=Payne|first=E.A.|publisher=Rowan Tree Books|year=2011|isbn=978-0615714912|location=|pages=141}}</ref> to 10,000<ref name="Vulture" /> reviews per posted chapter, most of which were negative and contained [[Flaming (Internet)|flaming]].<ref name="TheVerge"/><ref name=":0" /> The quality of the writing and the author's apparently [[Goth subculture|Goth]] lifestyle also drew attacks and mockery from users on [[Encyclopedia Dramatica]], [[TV Tropes]], [[LiveJournal]], [[Something Awful]], [[YTMND]], and [[YouTube]].<ref name="Vulture" />
Rob Bricken of [[io9]] described the work as a "masterpiece of weirdness" and a "masterpiece of literary disaster".<ref name="io9"/> Mathilda Gregory of [[BuzzFeed]] called ''My Immortal'' a "work of comic genius" that is "oddly touching."<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.buzzfeed.com/mathildia/he-put-his-boys-thingy-in-mine|title=The Gloriously Immortal Life of “My Immortal”|last=Gregory|first=Mathilda|date=February 19, 2016|website=|publisher=[[BuzzFeed]]|accessdate=August 20, 2016|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160916070128/https://www.buzzfeed.com/mathildia/he-put-his-boys-thingy-in-mine|archivedate=September 16, 2016|df=}}</ref>
===Legacy=== The work is often cited as the worst fan fiction ever written<ref name="Vulture"/><ref name="TheVerge" /><ref name="TheMarySue"/> or at least a "strong contender" for the title.<ref name="DailyDot"/> The work is considered "iconic" not only within the [[Harry Potter fandom|''Harry Potter'' fandom]] but also within the larger fan fiction community.<ref name="DailyDot" /><ref name="TheMarySue" />
The infamy of the work is considered a "constant millstone around the necks of fanfiction enthusiasts who struggle to bring legitimacy to the genre".<ref name="Vulture" /> Christo claimed in September 2017 that ''My Immortal'' is a work of satire, though any evidence of this is tied to her own claims of authorship.<ref name=":1">{{Cite web|url=http://www.vulture.com/2017/09/my-immortal-rose-christo-under-the-same-stars.html|title=Alleged Author of Legendarily Bad Fanfic ‘My Immortal’ Steps Forward, Announces Book Deal|last=Reisman |first=Abraham |date=September 7, 2017|publisher=[[Vulture (website) |Vulture]]|access-date=September 11, 2017}}</ref>
===Derivative works=== ''My Immortal'' inspired further [[fan work]]s, including [[fan art]] and further fan fiction. It was the subject of numerous [[YouTube]] [[dramatic reading]]s intending to mock the work,<ref name="Vulture"/> and it later inspired a fifteen-episode web series satirizing the work.<ref name="Vulture" /><ref name="DailyDot" />
